awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Mitigating Scaling in Membrane Distillation used for High-Salinity Wastewater Treatment
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the improved capability to manage wastewater. It is crucial to develop technologies that can reliably and efficiently treat the large volume of high-salinity brine produced daily around the world; currently, the most common treatment strategies suffer from high costs and detrimental environmental outcomes. The aim is to identify technology gaps that motivate the establishment of targeted treatment strategies leveraging both efficient operational design and sustainable energy sources for reduced wastewater management costs. Such technology may be commercially attractive to industrial facilities with regulatory and economic concerns. This project will work toward the development of commercially viable products that can sustainably address water scarcity while maintaining satisfactory environmental stewardship.
	
This I-Corps project involves the technological advancement of membrane distillation (MD), a thermal desalination process with the capability of harnessing low-grade waste heat to treat hypersaline brine. This advantage has led MD to be actively explored as a promising technology for brine management and zero-liquid discharge systems. However, a major challenge is membrane scaling, or mineral crystal formation/deposition on the membrane surface. Membrane scaling results in process failure in the form of membrane blockage and/or decreased salt rejection.  A new technology combines superhydrophobic membranes and periodic air purging, as neither solution is sufficient alone for long-term scaling mitigation. This project will inform the technology roadmap for advancing MD toward brine treatment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Broader impact: The broader impact of this project is to improve the ability to treat high salinity brines with membrane distillation (MD), enabling the practical application MD for minimal to zero liquid discharge wastewater treatment systems. Millions of gallons of high salinity brines produced daily by industry and municipalities are environmentally discharged, which poses severe environmental concerns, or are treated and recycled for reuse, which poses significant energy costs. Increasing water scarcity and environmental concerns are shifting brine management practices from discharge to recovery and reuse, thus, technology that can treat these brines in an energy efficient and reliable manner are in high demand.

 

Intellectual merit: The intellectual merit of this project is in identifying the problems encountered with the current brine management practices and how they can be improved. More specifically, is there market demand for membrane distillation (MD) in brine management strategies, what are the problems associated with it, and how can value be added to the process. These findings help gauge the market demand for improved fouling/scaling mitigation strategies in MD and guide the need for further technology development for high salinity brine management.

The goal of the NSF I-Corps program is to gauge the market demand for technologies developed under previous NSF awards and use this information to guide next steps for entering the market with said technology. This I-Corps team developed a scaling mitigation strategy for MD that enabled higher recovery operation by incorporating periodic air purging with superhydrophobic membranes. The team conducted over 170 customer discovery interviews with potential vendors, end-users, and competitors to identify the challenges and needs in high salinity brine management, especially with regard to membrane distillation. The team aimed to understand where and how their developed technology may fit into the market and what value it may add over existing technologies.

The state-of-the-art water treatment technology, reverse osmosis (RO), is used almost universally in any water treatment process for industry (power, manufacturing, chemical processing) use to municipal drinking water use. In the US, there is not much motivation to push water recovery any further beyond the RO step due to lack of regulation and/or large capital and operating costs associated with the additional water treatment technologies. For example, a typical minimal to zero liquid discharge (ZLD) water treatment train uses evaporative concentration and crystallization processes that account for over two-thirds of the energy consumption costs for the entire water treatment process and cannot often be justified without motivation from environmental regulation or water scarcity. Some areas with greater water scarcity issues and stricter regulation such as the arid southwest US, India, and China have began to push industry to implement ZLD practices.

Through the customer discovery process, the team learned there are two important roles that exist in the water treatment service industry. 1) EPC firms that engineer, install, and often operate the water treatment facility, and 2) vendors that supply the specific water treatment process units such as RO units or brine evaporators. Typically, if the EPC firms do not already own and manufacture their own process equipment, they will purchase from the vendors.

Our ideal market strategy would be to license our scaling mitigation strategy to an existing MD vendor because even though MD is in its earlier stages of industrial application, several MD vendors currently exist in the market and would be very difficult to compete with as a vendor ourselves. Through customer discovery interviews with these existing MD vendors and end-users of their products the team found scaling is not a major issue even when the brine was concentrated to 250-300,000 ppm, near the solubility limit. The reason for this was previously mentioned, nearly all modern water treatment processes have RO units incorporated that exist before MD in the process treatment train. To enable higher recovery and robust performance in RO, the scaling ions have already been chemically or physically pretreated to inhibit scaling on the RO membranes. Thus, the RO brine sent downstream to MD for further concentrating has already been treated for scaling ions and thus scaling is not a major problem for current MD processes even when pushing to such high concentrations.  

Furthermore, the team was unable to secure the intellectual property for our technology due to an existing patent. Thus, our only option for entering the market would be to enter and compete as an MD vendor. This option did not seem feasible and overall, the team decided to pivot our research efforts to address the challenges the team identified during the I-Corps program – energy consumption in the downstream ZLD process.

Modified by: Shihong Lin
